user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleUnload:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleUnload(osal_id_t module_id)
{
    OS_module_internal_record_t *module;
    int32                        return_code;
    OS_object_token_t            token;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, module_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        module = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_module_table, token);

        /*
         * Only call the implementation if the file was actually loaded.
         * If this is a static module, then this is just a placeholder and
         * it means there was no file actually loaded.
         */
        if (module->module_type == OS_MODULE_TYPE_DYNAMIC)
        {
            return_code = OS_ModuleUnload_Impl(&token);
        }

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are used in the presented code fragment. The source contains only standard C constructs: a function definition, local variable declarations, if-statement, structure member access, comparisons, function/macro calls and comments. There are no occurrences of common compiler-extension markers such as __attribute__, __asm, __builtin_*, __typeof__, __extension__, __thread, inline assembly, statement-expressions ({ ... }) or other vendor-specific keywords that would directly indicate a language extension.

Note: Several identifiers here are macros or project typedefs (for example OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_ModuleUnload_Impl, int32, OS_module_internal_record_t, OS_object_token_t). Those macro/typedef definitions are not visible in this fragment and could themselves use compiler-specific extensions internally. However, invoking a macro or using a typedef in this code does not by itself prove use of a language extension, so these call sites are not flagged. To fully confirm compliance, the definitions of those macros/typedefs should be reviewed separately; only their definitions (not the call sites shown) could contain the language extensions that Rule 1.2 forbids.
